PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? One.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Usually (not about once a month).

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? Usually on Sundays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Often invited to other homes.

5. What time of the day did you go? In the afternoon and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

6. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes.

7. How were always a meal served at any time? It would have been served.

8. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make polite" used, or was some other expression common?)

9. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

10. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? We all went.

11. Did you ever have these "home gatherings" in a building, make quilts, or other such activities? Yes.

12. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the ideas were for, and how often they occurred.

13. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

14. Did the family always have a house? Yes.

15. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.? No.

16. Were there any definite times, but not fixed, when we were having an event? Sometimes the family always went out and we were having an event.

17. Did you make it a real surprise, so that not everybody knew and had a lot of fun, everybody went, and enjoyed seeing each other?
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

Planning Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? One.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? One.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once a month.

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays, or other days? Other days.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Most visiting done without an invitation.

5. What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon?

6. Did you ever have parties when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activities? Yes.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the reasons were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, what drives or dances in homes? Describe.

The only parties we had were surprise parties in the woods.

People would gather from a radius of 15 miles come over and have a good time.

Here at least once a year, and we would have a hay ride.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from house to house, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? I have been one definite time, but not like a party.

Connect the family closer, was not why we were having our fires.

To make it a real surprise, we had our own refreshments, and had a lot of fun. Everybody went, no springing anyone.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE,

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About five.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? One.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Usually only about once a month.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Occasionally other days—occasionally on Sundays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? We were invited for an invitation, and we were also.

What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, there was always a meal at any time, but it would have been.

How was the invitation to a meal phrased when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "taste patluok" used, or was some other expression common?) I believe "pot luck" was the usual expression.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place? We all went.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

The only party we had was surprise parties in the spring.

People would gather from a radius of two miles and have a story all night at parties. They would have had our children there, you see.

Here these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, once a week, once every two weeks, once a month, etc.?

In the olden days, games were popular. Such as - card games, animal - vegetable - mineral, the quilt basket, musical chairs, animal - vegetable - mineral, in which two groups formed circles, and kept track to find the animal, vegetable, or mineral. Cards were also very popular, a game to an object placed in a box, and the player had to find out what was inside by feeling.

Writing, poetry, and songs were also popular.

There was great excitement when the first settlers arrived in the little town located near the railroad.

They had come to Canada with three families and a few servants.

The ladies worked hard in the kitchen while the men worked in the fields.

During the winter months, sewing and knitting were common activities.

We would put in many hours playing which would relax our hearts.
